question.title: Quarkus test reactive failure
question.body:
I have the following resource:

@Path("/config")
@RequiredArgsConstructor
public class Resource {

  private final Service service;

  @PUT
  @Consumes(MediaType.APPLICATION_JSON)
  @Produces(MediaType.APPLICATION_JSON)
  public Uni<Response> putConfig(List<Config> configs) {
    return service.updateConfig(configs)
        .map(ignored -> Response.noContent().build())
        .onFailure().recoverWithItem(ignored -> Response.serverError().build());
  }

}

and the corresponding tests:

@QuarkusTest
class ResourceTest {

  @InjectMock
  Service service;

  @Test
  void putConfigOk() {
    final var request = mockConfig();

    when(service.updateConfig(request)).thenReturn(Uni.createFrom().voidItem());

    given()
        .body(request)
        .contentType(MediaType.APPLICATION_JSON)
        .when().put("/config")
        .then()
        .statusCode(204);
  }

  @Test
  void putConfigFails() {
    final var request = mockConfig();

    when(service.updateConfig(request)).thenReturn(Uni.createFrom().failure(RuntimeException::new));

    given()
        .body(request)
        .contentType(MediaType.APPLICATION_JSON)
        .when().put("/config")
        .then()
        .statusCode(500);
  }

  private List<Config> mockConfig() {
    return List.of(new Config());
  }

}

First test runs perfectly, returns 204. However, second test still returns 204. I don't know what I'm doing wrong. In fact, running test with coverage shows failure part is never covered... Any ideas?

question_comments.body: No, I do not think that RestAssured mainpulates anything. I suspect that the .equals()-method is the issue.
@Turing85 You are right! Changing them to any() works. So I guess that request is being manipulated somehow by RestAssured... thanks! I can validate your answer if you write it down properly

My suspicion is that the parameter is not properly matched This can be confirmed by calling Mockito.verify(...) on the mocked method. Is there a specific reason to call when(service.updateConfig(request))... instead of when(service.UpdateConfig(any())...? --- If you can provide to a git repo, I can take a look.
